Award.AwardTitle: Sustainable use of water and soils in seasonally-dry regions: exploring the continuum between natural and intensively-managed ecosystems

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project will support an international collaboration among researchers at Duke University, investigators in Brazil and Burkina Faso (Africa), and colleagues at ETH-Zurich and EPFL-Lausanne (Switzerland). The project is designed to quantitatively assess water use and soil-plant relationships in two distinct environments subject to strong, yet variable, wet and long dry seasons. In Brazil, the region under consideration has a longstanding sustainable agriculture initiative, whereas in Burkina Faso there are challenges with land management and deforestation. The research will combine models of plant and soil processes to assess the eco-hydrology of tropical dry ecosystems. This will generate tools that could be used to improve sustainable management of these fragile ecosystems. The collaborative efforts will identify environmental, climate, and socioeconomic drivers of land use decisions, and understanding these drivers will increase the sustainability of agricultural production under current land use and potential climate change scenarios. Collaboration with social scientists will enhance the impact of the research. Graduate and undergraduate students will receive training in a highly interdisciplinary environment, and will have a unique opportunity to learn, at an early stage of their careers, the value of international partnerships.

This grant is co-funded by the Office of International Science and Engineering (OISE), Switzerland and Africa, Near East, and South Asia (ANESA) programs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Sustainable use of soil and water resources requires optimizing the use of water for irrigation, in combination with a choice of suitable crops and management practices. This problem is especially important in the seasonally dry tropics, which are characterized by clear sequences of wet and dry seasons. As a first result in this project, we analyzed how plants and soil nutrient cycling respond to this sequence of dry and wet periods, allowing us to characterize the timing of water stress and reduced nutrient availability for plant growth (both natural and in rainfed agriculture). We also analyzed extensive historical rainfall records in the tropics and developed new statistical quantities to quantify the degree of seasonality in each region. The results of the study, published (among other journal papers published in more specialized journals) in the journal Nature Climate Change, show that the wet season in many regions of the tropics has become more uncertain in time (in terms of amount of rainfall as well as timing and duration of the wet season). Such trends, which are also present in the simulations of future climates in global circulation models (that is planetary scale climate models), are potentially very problematic for sustainable agriculture and water resources availability in these regions.

The second part of the project focused on developing mathematical models to compute the amounts of water needed for irrigation in these conditions of changing and uncertain climates. These water requirements were quantified depending on the type of crop and method of irrigation and then compared in terms of water savings, costs of water and crop yield. These methods and results are useful to assess, improve and plan agricultural efforts ensuring productivity without harming the environment.
